Ammonia, present in the atmosphere in just a few parts per billion, seems to enhance the harmful effects on trees of sulfur dioxide, the main component of acid rain, researchers in England say.

The scientists, A. R. McLeod and colleagues from the National Power Technology and Environmental Center in Surrey and at Imperial College in Berkshire, studied Norway spruce, Sitka spruce and Scots pine, three common European conifers.

On its own, sulfur dioxide gas dissolves in the water on a wet leaf, increasing the acidity of the water. But when alkaline ammonia is present, the water can hold much more sulfur dioxide. The ammonia also dissolves and releases nitrogen, an essential nutrient.

Up to a point, the nitrogen may promote growth. But ultimately too much nitrogen can upset the chemical balance of the trees and the soil and contribute to the decline of European forests, the scientists said.

''The interaction between ammonia and sulfur dioxide was completely unexpected,'' said one researcher, R. A. Skeffington, adding that the findings complicate the concept of ''critical load,'' the threshold suggested by some scientists below which a pollutant would not be harmful.
